title: How to Make Party Favors from Candy

steps.headline: Choose the candy bag.
steps.description: It is probably best to choose a bag that matches the party theme. If making your own, either paper or cellophane bags can be used. Paper bags can be jazzed up with drawings, patterns, stamps, etc. ; while cellophane bags can be improved with stickers or glued-on images. Choose colors matching the party theme.

steps.headline: Select the candies.
steps.description: The candies can be matched to the party theme or simply chosen because you know the kids like certain kinds. Be mindful of any allergies when choosing the candies. If you're not sure, steer clear especially of candies containing nuts. Other allergens include milk, egg, soy and gluten.

steps.headline: Make up portions of the same size for each bag.
steps.description: Tip the candies into the bags.

steps.headline: Tie the bag or knot it.
steps.description: Finish with a ribbon or yarn bow.

steps.headline: Purchase a bag of skewers.
steps.description: Also buy lots of soft candies that can be pierced easily by the skewer. Get as many skewers as party guests needing a party favor. A few spares won't hurt either, in case some snap while working with them.

steps.headline: Plan the skewer design.
steps.description: Arrange all of the candies on a clean tray or large plate. Play around with placement of each type of candy to form a line that will sit on the skewer. When you're happy with the design, start making the skewers.

steps.headline: Set up a manufacturing line.
steps.description: Place the designed skewer in front of you for guidance, and each candy type in order of the template design.

steps.headline: Pierce each candy into place on the first skewer.
steps.description: Set that skewer aside on a plate and move onto the next one. Repeat until all of the skewers are done.

steps.headline: Cover with long cellophane bags.
steps.description: If you can't find cellophane bags, make cellophane covers from plain cellophane and tape in place. Finish off with a ribbon bow at the base to keep the bag in place.

steps.headline: Done.
steps.description: The candy party favors are now ready for sharing out.

steps.headline: Visit the dollar store.
steps.description: Look for small spice jars or jars of a similar small and cylinder shape. They must have decent lids on them, to keep the contents safely inside.

steps.headline: Get small candies that will fit inside the little jars.
steps.description: Small candy-coated chocolates, jelly beans, tiny boiled sweets, etc. are ideal for adding.

steps.headline: Fill each jar.
steps.description: Decide whether you'll only use one type of candy or layer different candies before filling. If layering, do at least three layers to make it look effective. Then place the lid on top. It may be a good idea to tape down the lid if it's not tight enough on its own.

steps.headline: Decorate the jar.
steps.description: This can be done in many ways, some suggestions include tying a ribbon bow around the neck of the jar, piercing a miniature windmill through the top if the lid is made from cork, adding a label with the birthday party date and the guest's name, adding stickers or scrapbook cutouts, and so forth.

steps.headline: Purchase large lollipops.
steps.description: You'll need one per guest.

steps.headline: Design a birthday party logo on your computer.
steps.description: It must be able to fit onto the lollipop. Include a message such as "Thank you for coming to Melissa's birthday party" and any pictures, patterns or designs you'd like.

steps.headline: Print off as many as needed for each lollipop.
steps.description: Cut around them to fit the lollipop.

steps.headline: Glue onto each lollipop.
steps.description: Finish off with a small ribbon tied around the lollipop stick.

steps.headline: Done.
steps.description: This is a nice, easy way to make a candy party favor that also serves as a memento.

steps.headline: Purchase orange tulle (net), orange jellybeans or candies, orange or brown rubber bands and brown pipe cleaners (chenille sticks).
Draw a large circle on a piece of thin card.
steps.description: This is the template for cutting out the tulle circles. It must be large enough so that when the tulle is gathered, it holds about a handful of the candies inside the tulle.

steps.headline: Place the template onto the tulle.
steps.description: Cut out as many circles as you need to make candy party favors.

steps.headline: Fill the first tulle circle with candy.
steps.description: Then draw up all of the circle edges of the tulle to the center top, holding it with your fingers. There needs to be enough tulle meeting in the center to allow for you to wrap the chenille stick around it. If not, remove some of the candies; you'll get a sense for how many candies to add as you keep making more pumpkins.

steps.headline: Use the rubber band to hold the tulle top in place.
steps.description: Wrap it around to fit tightly, so that no candies can escape.

steps.headline: Wind the brown pipe cleaner around the tulle top.
steps.description: This forms the pumpkin stem. As it leaves the tulle, continue to wind the top part of the pipe cleaner into a standalone spiral. This finishes off the look.

steps.headline: Repeat until all of the pumpkins needed have been made.
steps.description: These make great Halloween party favors or they can be given out at the door for trick and treaters.

text: Basic candy party favor bag Choose the candy bag. It is probably best to choose a bag that matches the party theme. If making your own, either paper or cellophane bags can be used. Paper bags can be jazzed up with drawings, patterns, stamps, etc. ; while cellophane bags can be improved with stickers or glued-on images. Choose colors matching the party theme. Select the candies. The candies can be matched to the party theme or simply chosen because you know the kids like certain kinds. Be mindful of any allergies when choosing the candies. If you're not sure, steer clear especially of candies containing nuts. Other allergens include milk, egg, soy and gluten. Make up portions of the same size for each bag. Tip the candies into the bags. Tie the bag or knot it. Finish with a ribbon or yarn bow. Candy skewer Purchase a bag of skewers. Also buy lots of soft candies that can be pierced easily by the skewer. Get as many skewers as party guests needing a party favor. A few spares won't hurt either, in case some snap while working with them. Plan the skewer design. Arrange all of the candies on a clean tray or large plate. Play around with placement of each type of candy to form a line that will sit on the skewer. When you're happy with the design, start making the skewers. Set up a manufacturing line. Place the designed skewer in front of you for guidance, and each candy type in order of the template design. Pierce each candy into place on the first skewer. Set that skewer aside on a plate and move onto the next one. Repeat until all of the skewers are done. Cover with long cellophane bags. If you can't find cellophane bags, make cellophane covers from plain cellophane and tape in place. Finish off with a ribbon bow at the base to keep the bag in place. Done. The candy party favors are now ready for sharing out. Candy jars Visit the dollar store. Look for small spice jars or jars of a similar small and cylinder shape. They must have decent lids on them, to keep the contents safely inside. Get small candies that will fit inside the little jars. Small candy-coated chocolates, jelly beans, tiny boiled sweets, etc. are ideal for adding. Fill each jar. Decide whether you'll only use one type of candy or layer different candies before filling. If layering, do at least three layers to make it look effective. Then place the lid on top. It may be a good idea to tape down the lid if it's not tight enough on its own. Decorate the jar. This can be done in many ways, some suggestions include tying a ribbon bow around the neck of the jar, piercing a miniature windmill through the top if the lid is made from cork, adding a label with the birthday party date and the guest's name, adding stickers or scrapbook cutouts, and so forth. Easy lollipop Purchase large lollipops. You'll need one per guest. Design a birthday party logo on your computer. It must be able to fit onto the lollipop. Include a message such as "Thank you for coming to Melissa's birthday party" and any pictures, patterns or designs you'd like. Print off as many as needed for each lollipop. Cut around them to fit the lollipop. Glue onto each lollipop. Finish off with a small ribbon tied around the lollipop stick. Done. This is a nice, easy way to make a candy party favor that also serves as a memento. Halloween pumpkins Purchase orange tulle (net), orange jellybeans or candies, orange or brown rubber bands and brown pipe cleaners (chenille sticks).  Draw a large circle on a piece of thin card. This is the template for cutting out the tulle circles. It must be large enough so that when the tulle is gathered, it holds about a handful of the candies inside the tulle. Place the template onto the tulle. Cut out as many circles as you need to make candy party favors. Fill the first tulle circle with candy. Then draw up all of the circle edges of the tulle to the center top, holding it with your fingers. There needs to be enough tulle meeting in the center to allow for you to wrap the chenille stick around it. If not, remove some of the candies; you'll get a sense for how many candies to add as you keep making more pumpkins. Use the rubber band to hold the tulle top in place. Wrap it around to fit tightly, so that no candies can escape. Wind the brown pipe cleaner around the tulle top. This forms the pumpkin stem. As it leaves the tulle, continue to wind the top part of the pipe cleaner into a standalone spiral. This finishes off the look. Repeat until all of the pumpkins needed have been made. These make great Halloween party favors or they can be given out at the door for trick and treaters. Finished.
